children.name: to try sth to see if it is good
try
children.definition: to do or use something for a short while to discover if it is suitable, successful, enjoyable etc: thử
examples: It works really well – you should try it.

children.name: try doing something
examples: They decided they would try living in America for a while.
Try logging off and logging on again.

children.name: try sth new/different(= do or use something that is different from what you usually do or use )
examples: If I'm going out for a meal, I prefer to try something different.

children.name: try sth on sb/sth
examples: We tried the machine on hardwood and soft wood.

children.name: try somebody on something
examples: Petra’s trying the baby on solid foods.

children.name: try sth for size(= put on a piece of clothing or test something to find out if it is the correct size or suitable )
examples: Always try a sleeping bag for size before you buy it.

children.name: Grammar
examples: If youtry to do something, you attempt to succeed in doing it :
We must try to prevent this happening.
If youtry doing something, you do it in order to find out if it is enjoyable or produces the result you want :
Try using margarine instead of butter.

children.name: try out
children.definition: to use a new method, a new product, or that you have learned, in order to find out how good, how successful, or how suitable it is: thử
examples: They sell paint in very small cans so you can try out the different colours at home.
It was six months before she had a chance to try her songs out in front of a live audience.
I’m trying out a new computer.

children.name: try out onto practise a skill in order to improve it
examples: Dietmar enjoyed trying out his English on American troops stationed in Berlin.
She enjoyed trying her French out on Jean-Pierre.

children.name: experiment with
children.definition: experiment

children.name: give sth a try
children.definition: to try using or doing sth, although you are not sure if it will succeed or if it is suitable or good:
examples: I’m not sure that writing to complain will do much good, but we can give it a try.
Why don’t we give that new wine bar a try?

children.name: sample
children.definition: to try an activity, go to a place etc in order to see what it is like: thử

children.name: sample the delight/pleasure of sth
examples: The hotel provides an excellent base from which visitors can sample the delights of scuba diving and waterskiing.
So you're going to sample thedelights/pleasuresof the new restaurant?
Here’s your chance tosample the delights ofcountry life.

children.name: have a go
children.definition: /bash UK informal to do sth for the first time to see whether you can do it, whether you enjoy it etc:
examples: ▪She’s never tried skiing before, but she’s willing to have a go.
The competition’s open to anyone, so why not have a bash?

children.name: have a go/bash at doing sth
examples: Most kids get the opportunity to have a bash at writing poetry when they’re at school.

children.name: have a go on sthtry using a machine
examples: Can I have a go on your computer?

children.name: try your hand at
children.definition: to try an activity that is new to you and that interests you, especially sth that you need to learn special skills for: thử bắt tay vào
examples: ▪ He first tried his hand at motor racing in 1963, but without much success.

children.name: try your hand at doing sth
examples: ▪ After she lost her job, she thought she’d try her hand at writing a novel.

children.name: trial and error
children.definition: the process of trying a lot of different ways of doing sth, in order to find out which one works best:
examples: by/through trial and errorif you do something by trial and error, you test many different methods of doing something in order to find the best :
I learned most of what I know about gardening through trial and error.
We found out by trial and error which plants could survive the dry conditions.

children.name: a process of trial and error
examples: We learn new skills through a process of trial and error.
There's no instant way of finding a cure - it's just aprocess oftrial and error.

children.name: to do a test on sth in order to check it or find out about it
thí nghiệm , kiểm tra
examples: ▪ He has a blood test done each week to see how effective the medication is.
▪ Children can use the magnet to perform many simple experiments.
▪ The company did not conduct adequate safety tests.

children.name: do a test/an experiment on
examples: ▪ The space shuttle crew conducted experiments on plants and cells in a special lab.

children.name: test
children.definition: to do a test on something to find out whether it works or to get more information about it: kiểm tra
examples: Test your brakes to check they are working correctly.
The devices were tested very carefully and are considered safe.

children.name: test sth on somebody/something
examples: These products have not been tested on animals.

children.name: test sth for sthto find out whether it has a substance in it
examples: The water is being tested for signs of chemical pollution.
They tested her bloodforsigns of the infection.

children.name: run a test
children.definition: to do a test, especially one that is often used, or one that has been prepared and is ready to be done:
examples: ▪ Doctors ran tests to determine the cause of his irregular heartbeat.
▪ We think the equipment is working fine, but we still need to run a few more tests.

children.name: carry out tests
children.definition: if sb such as a doctor or scientist carries out tests, they do a set of tests in order to find out what is wrong, what needs improving etc:
examples: ▪ Police scientists are carrying out tests on the murder victim’s clothes.
▪ Results of tests carried out at this clinic are always strictly confidential.

children.name: try out
children.definition: to test an object such as a tool or piece of equipment by using it, or to test a plan or idea by doing it:
examples: ▪ Toy manufacturers use employees’ children to try new products out.
▪ He visited the center several times, trying out different computer software packages.

children.name: put sth to the test
children.definition: to test sth, such as an idea, a belief, or a product, to see if it works as well as sb says it does or as you think it will: đem ra thử (xem có đúng không)
examples: The system’s effectiveness will soon be put to the test.
The soldiers worked out a strategy which was then put to the test in a training exercise.

children.name: pilot
children.definition: to test a new system or product using different groups of people in order to see how effective or popular it is: thử thí điểm
examples: The coursebook was piloted in schools all over Europe.

children.name: a test on sth to check it or find out about it
test
children.definition: 1 machine/producta process used to discover whether equipment or a product works correctly, or to discover more about it: thử nghiệm
examples: nuclear weapons tests
test for
a test for chemicals in the water
test on
We carry out safety tests on all our products.
test to determine/show/find etc
Teachers can use the program to create tests to check children’s progress.
Laboratory testsshow that the new drug is very effective.
A nuclear device was detonated at the Trinity test site in New Mexico, on July 16, 1945.
We went to thetest sitein Nevada.
2 difficult situationa difficult situation in which the qualities of someone or something are clearly shown : kiểm tra
Chess player Nigel Short faces Anatoly Karpov in the toughest test of his career so far.
test of character/strength/courage/endurance etc
The problems she faced were a real test of character.

children.name: laboratory tests
examples: Independent laboratory tests have confirmed that the product works very successfully.

children.name: a test site
children.definition: a place where something can be tested

children.name: experiment
children.definition: a scientific test to find out how sth is affected when you do sth to it: thí nghiệm (khoa học)
examples: experiment with/in/on
experiments with alcohol-fuelled cars
experiments on sleep deprivation
by experiment
Many small birds guide themselves by the stars, as has been verified by experiment.
do/carry out an experimentThey carried out a series of experiments to test the theory.|He did some experiments with bats.
perform/conduct an experimentformal(= do an experiment )The laboratory began conducting experiments on rats.

an experiment shows/proves/demonstrates somethingHis experiment showed that lightning was a kind of electricity.|The experiment proved that fabrics treated with the chemical are much less likely to catch fire.
COMMON ERRORS
►Do not say 'make an experiment'. Saycarry out an experimentordo an experiement.
experimental[adj] C2used for, relating to, or resulting from experiments
an experimental medical treatment
experimental evidence/results/data
A hypothesis is tested by finding experimental evidence for it.
experimental work/studies
experimental studies on birds and animals
experimental animals
experimentally[adv]
The FDA has granted researchers permission to use the drug experimentally on humans.

children.name: a scientific experiment
examples: Astronauts performed scientific experiments during the flight.

children.name: animal experiments
children.definition: experiments using animals
examples: I think most animal experiments are cruel and unnecessary.

children.name: a laboratory experiment
children.definition: one that takes place in a laboratory
examples: They did a series of laboratory experiments on human sleep patterns in the 1960s.

children.name: a field experiment
children.definition: one that takes place in the real world, not in a laboratory
examples: In field experiments, we used patients who did not know that it was a test situation.

children.name: a controlled experiment
children.definition: one that is done using correct scientific methods
examples: The theory has not yet been tested by a properly controlled experiment.

children.name: a practical experiment
children.definition: one that relates to real situations or events, not scientific theories
examples: The research team compiled a set of practical experiments in Modern Astronomy.

children.name: an experiment to test/measure/find out something
examples: We did an experiment to test the acidity of the soil.

children.name: trial
children.definition: 1 test a process of testing to find out whether sth works effectively and is safe:
examples: Results of the drug trial will be available soon.
trial of
Probert is overseeing the trials of the new explosives.
clinical triala trial of a drug or treatment that is done carefully by doctors on humans : thử nghiệm lâm sàng
Until now, the drug was only available to people taking part in clinical trials.
a new drug that is undergoingclinical trials
2 try somebody/something[] a short period during which you use or do sth or employ sb to find out whether they are satisfactory for a particular purpose or job →try: dùng thử, làm thử
on trial
They let me have the computer on trial for thirty days.
trial period
The security system will be reviewed after a three-monthtrial period.
They've employed her for a six-month trial(period).
Smith was hiredona six-monthtrial basis.
mainly UKYou can buy any of their garden equipmentontrial/ US usuallyon atrialbasis, and if you don't like it you can give it back.
trial separation(= a period of time in which a husband and wife do not live together, to find out whether they want to stay married )

children.name: testing N
children.definition: testing formal when something such as a process, system, substance etc is being examined, in order to see whether it exists, is safe, or is working properly:
examples: ▪ The U.S. conducted atomic weapons testing in Nevada during the 1950s.
▪ The aircraft is still in the early stages of testing and production.

children.name: drug/genetic/AIDS etc testing
examples: ▪ Athletes will be subject to random drug testing.

children.name: trial run
children.definition: an occasion when you test a new method or system to see if it works well:
examples: This year is something of a trial run for the new service.
The national railroad is doing a few trial runs to test new equipment.

children.name: pilot
children.definition: a test in which a new idea or plan is used in a limited number of places or situations, in order to see if it is worth continuing or doing in a more general way: thí điểm
examples: The results of the pilot have been encouraging.

children.name: pilot study/project/program etc
examples: The government sponsored a pilot project to find out how the education reforms would work inschools.

children.name: a pilot scheme which could be extended to other areas
piloting N
children.definition: piloting  a process in which a new system or product is tested using different groups of people in order to see how effective and popular it will be:
examples: ▪ Extensive piloting has shown us our study book will be a useful aid to students.

children.name: to use a person or animal in a test
experiment on
children.definition: to use sb/sth in scientific tests in order to find out how they are affected when you do something to them: làm thí nghiệm trên
examples: For some disease research, experimenting on animals is very important.
Some of the government labs had experimented on humans without their consent.
Experimentingonmice can give us an idea of the effect of the disease in humans.

children.name: test sth on
children.definition: sb/sth to do tests in which a group of people or animals use a product, take a drug etc in order to see what their reaction is:
examples: This face cream has not been tested on animals.
They’ve just received permission to begin testing the new drug on humans.

children.name: vivisection
children.definition: the practice of doing tests on live animals, for example in order to increase medical knowledge or to test new products: thí nghiệm trên động vật
examples: I’m not against vivisection, but obviously we all want to avoid animals suffering unnecessarily.
Without vivisection many of the recent anti-cancer advances simply would not have been made.

children.name: a person or animal that is used in a test
subject
children.definition: a person or animal that is used in a test - use this especially inscientificcontexts: đối tượng
examples: ▪ Subjects for this experiment represented a good cross-section of the American population.
▪ All subjects were tested for perfect hearing before the experiment began.

children.name: guinea pig
children.definition: a person or animal who takes part in a test to see how successful or useful a new idea, system, machine etc is, sometimes without being asked: chuột bạch
examples: ▪ Would you both mind being the guinea pigs for a new recipe I want to try out?
▪ Students are complaining that they are being used as guinea pigs for the new maths syllabus.

children.name: experiment
children.definition: a process in which you test a new idea or method to see if it is useful or effective
examples: experiment with/in/on
an experiment in state socialism
an experimental theatre group

children.name: a bold experiment
children.definition: one that tries to achieve a lot and takes risks
examples: The country's bold experiment with economic reform has not paid off yet.

children.name: a unique experiment
children.definition: one that has not been done before
examples: Congestion charging is a unique experiment that other UK cities are watching with interest.

children.name: a democratic/socialist/communist experiment
children.definition: one in which a country tries a new political system
examples: He went to Havana to judge for himself the success or failure of the socialist experiment.

children.name: a social experiment
children.definition: one in which people try a new way of living and organizing society
examples: The community started out as a social experiment.

children.name: experimental[adj]
examples: C2using new ideas or methods :
